questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents to the ophthalmologist and is found to have anterior uveitis. Upon enquiry, he has mouth ulcers and a rash on his leg. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This case (oral ulcers + leg rash + anterior uveitis) is classic for Behçet syndrome.

Behçet's syndrome is a multisystem relapsing vasculitis first described by Hulusi Behçet.

It is characterized by:

  • Mucocutaneous involvement: recurrent painful oral ulcers (~98%) and genital ulcers (~80%).
  • Eye disease: panuveitis or anterior/posterior uveitis (50%).
  • Skin: erythema nodosum, pseudofolliculitis, acneiform nodules.
  • It can also involve large veins/arteries, the CNS, and the GI tract.

Key diagnostic criteria (ISG Criteria)

Diagnosis: Recurrent oral ulcers + 2 of 4

  1. Genital ulcers (often scarring)
  2. Eye lesions (uveitis, retinal vasculitis)
  3. Skin lesions (erythema nodosum, papulopustular)
  4. Pathergy test positive (papule/pustule 24-48h after needle prick)

Explanation of other options:

AL Amyloidosis (Option A): Causes nephrotic syndrome, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and neuropathy. Does not present with mucosal ulcers or uveitis.

Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF) (Option B): Presents with recurrent fever, peritonitis, and polyserositis. No eye or mucocutaneous lesions like in Behçet's.

Polymyalgia Rheumatica (PMR) (Option D): Seen in age>50 with proximal stiffness and is linked with temporal arteritis. Does not cause ulcers, uveitis, or skin nodules.

Anterior Uveitis in Behcet's disease

Oral ulceration in Behcet's disease

questions.text: A 71-year-old man develops weakness of the shoulders and around the hips over 6 months. He has also noticed weak finger flexors. He complained of difficulty swallowing liquids. There is no other significant past medical history. He smokes 15 cigarettes a day and drinks a bottle of wine at the weekend. A creatinine kinase level comes back at 120 U/l.A muscle biopsy sample shows myopathic changes. There are also inflammatory. Infiltrates and intracytoplasmic vacuoles are present. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

This patient's presentation is classic for Inclusion Body Myositis (IBM):

Key clinical clues:

  • Age >50 years: IBM predominantly affects older adults (onset usually >50).
  • Pattern of weakness:
    • Proximal weakness (shoulders, hips)
    • Distal weakness, especially finger flexors and quadriceps. Finger flexor weakness is highly characteristic.
  • Dysphagia: Occurs in 40-66% of cases due to involvement of pharyngeal muscles.
  • Slow progression: Weakness develops over months to years.
  • CK levels: May be normal or mildly elevated (as in this case).
  • Muscle biopsy: Pathognomonic findings are:
    • Endomysial inflammation (like polymyositis)
    • Intracytoplasmic rimmed vacuoles and inclusion bodies (distinguish IBM from other inflammatory myopathies).

Explanation of other options:

Polymyositis (Option A): Typically affects proximal muscles only, sparing distal muscles. CK is usually markedly elevated. Finger flexor involvement and inclusion bodies are not seen.

Dermatomyositis (Option B): Presents with proximal weakness and skin manifestations (heliotrope rash, Gottron papules). CK is elevated; biopsy shows perifascicular atrophy and perivascular inflammation, not rimmed vacuoles.

Fibromyalgia (Option C): A chronic pain syndrome with widespread pain, fatigue, tender points; no objective muscle weakness, normal CK, and normal biopsy.

questions.text: A 25 year old man was noted by ophthalmologists to have a posterior uveitis requiring high dose immunosuppression. He has a history of recurrent mouth ulcers and painful ulcers on the scrotum.What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Behcet's syndrome is classically characterized as a triad of symptoms that include recurring crops of mouth ulcers (called apthous ulcers), genital ulcers, and uveitis. The ulcers are usually painful.

Typical eye involvement is bilateral pan uveitis.

In addition, iritis, retinal vessel occlusions and optic neuritis can be found. Hypopyon uveitis is a rare manifestation.

The arthritis of Behcet's disease is usually intermittent, self-limited, not deforming and localized to the knees and ankles.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents with a week's history of a painful right leg. He has had previous episodes of erythema nodosum, recurrent oral and scrotal ulceration. Examination reveals a diffusely swollen left leg. What is the likely cause of his swollen leg?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The clinical scenario is classic for Behçet's syndrome:

Key features in the question pointing to Behçet's:

  • Recurrent oral and genital ulcers (hallmark feature)
  • Erythema nodosum (skin involvement)
  • Painful, swollen leg → now presenting as a venous complication

Vascular involvement in Behçet's:

  • Behçet's is a systemic vasculitis that uniquely affects both arteries and veins.
  • Venous thrombosis (especially DVT) is more common than arterial lesions.
  • Thrombosis occurs due to vascular inflammation, not a hypercoagulable state.
  • Other vascular complications: superficial thrombophlebitis, IVC thrombosis, Budd-Chiari syndrome, pulmonary artery aneurysms.

Thus, the most likely cause of the leg swelling here is DVT secondary to Behçet's vasculitis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of arthralgia, painful mouth ulceration, and eye irritation. On examination, he had some ulceration in the mouth, bilaterally swollen wrists, and reduced range of movements of both knees. His investigations showed: white cell count 11 x 10^9/L, C-reactive protein 100 mg/dl, Rheumatoid factor negative. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

This patient has:

  • Recurrent painful oral ulcers
  • Eye involvement (irritation → possible uveitis)
  • Arthritis/arthralgia with swollen wrists and knee restriction
  • Negative rheumatoid factor (seronegative)
  • Raised inflammatory markers

These features strongly point to Behçet's syndrome.

Key Features of Behçet's syndrome:

  1. Classic triad:
    • Recurrent oral ulcers (seen in almost all patients, usually the first sign)
    • Genital ulcers
    • Eye lesions - anterior/posterior uveitis, hypopyon, or retinal vasculitis
  2. Other features:
    • Skin: erythema nodosum, papulopustular lesions
    • Joints: mono- or oligoarthritis, non-erosive
    • Pathergy: hyperreactivity to skin trauma
    • Vascular: superficial/deep venous thrombosis, arterial aneurysms
    • Neurological and GI involvement in some cases
  3. Diagnosis:
    • Based on clinical features (International Study Group criteria) - recurrent oral ulcers + 2 of genital ulcers, skin lesions, eye lesions, or positive pathergy test.

Explanation of other options:

Reiter's syndrome (Reactive arthritis) (Option A): Classically: urethritis, conjunctivitis, arthritis (can't see, can't pee, can't climb a tree). Typically follows an infection. Does not cause recurrent painful mouth ulcers.

Sjögren's syndrome (Option C): Characterized by dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia) due to autoimmune destruction of exocrine glands. Oral ulcers are not a feature.

Ankylosing spondylitis (Option D): Mainly involves the axial skeleton (sacroiliitis and spine). Does not cause recurrent oral ulcers or uveitis with arthritis in this pattern.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with a two-month history of progressive painless weakness affecting the proximal arms and legs. He has noticed difficulty getting out of a low chair and some difficulty swallowing, but denies any rashes or visual symptoms. Investigations show a CK of 5000 IU/l.Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

This case describes proximal, symmetrical, painless muscle weakness with a markedly elevated CK (5000 IU/L) and dysphagia.

These findings are characteristic of an inflammatory myopathy polymyositis.

Key features supporting Polymyositis

  1. Clinical presentation:
    • Gradual onset, symmetrical proximal muscle weakness (hips, shoulders).
    • Difficulty climbing stairs, rising from a chair, and lifting arms above the head.
    • Dysphagia occurs due to the involvement of pharyngeal muscles.
    • Pain is mild or absent (unlike PMR).
  2. Laboratory findings:
    • Very high creatine kinase (CK) and aldolase due to muscle breakdown.
    • May have positive ANA, anti-Jo-1 antibodies.
  3. Other features:
    • Ocular muscles are spared (unlike myasthenia gravis).
    • No rash (which would suggest dermatomyositis).
  4. Diagnosis confirmation:
    • EMG: myopathic pattern.
    • Muscle biopsy: endomysial inflammation with CD8+ T-cells.

Explanation of other options:

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) (Option A): Presents with acute ascending weakness, areflexia. CK is normal. Nerve (not muscle) pathology.

Hypothyroidism (Option B): Can cause myopathy and weakness, but CK levels are usually only mildly elevated (not 5000 IU/L). Other symptoms of hypothyroidism (weight gain, cold intolerance) would be present.

Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) (Option C): Causes pain and stiffness in proximal girdles, not true weakness. CK is normal.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with pain and stiffness of the small joints of the hands. She also has difficulty getting up from the chair. She has no dermatologic symptoms. On auscultation, she has fine Velcro crepitations in both basal lung fields. Which antibody is classically associated with this syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

This case is classic for Antisynthetase Syndrome, a subset of idiopathic inflammatory myopathies:

Key features pointing to the diagnosis:

  • Proximal muscle weakness (difficulty rising from a chair)
  • Interstitial lung disease (ILD) is evidenced by Velcro-like crepitations
  • Non-erosive arthritis (pain and stiffness of small joints)
  • Absence of skin findings of dermatomyositis

These features strongly suggest Antisynthetase Syndrome.

Antisynthetase Syndrome:

Definition
A multisystem autoimmune syndrome characterized by:

  • Myositis
  • ILD
  • Arthritis
  • Raynaud's phenomenon
  • Mechanic's hands
  • Fever

All associated with antibodies against aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases.

Antibody Association

  • The most common antibody is anti-Jo-1 (anti-histidyl-tRNA synthetase), seen in 25-35% of myositis cases.

Investigations

  • CK: Usually elevated due to myositis
  • Pulmonary function tests: Restrictive pattern due to ILD
  • HRCT chest: Honeycomb fibrosis
  • Muscle biopsy: Perimysial pathology with perifascicular necrosis and MAC deposition.

Prognosis and Treatment

  • Responds to immunosuppressants, but ILD can be refractory.
  • Unlike dermatomyositis or polymyositis, this syndrome is not associated with malignancy.

Explanation of other options:

Anti-MDA5 (Option A): Anti-MDA5 antibodies are seen in amyopathic dermatomyositis (DM without significant muscle weakness). These patients are at high risk for rapidly progressive interstitial lung disease (ILD) and cutaneous ulcerations, but they do not typically have the full Antisynthetase Syndrome triad.

Anti-PmScl (Option B): Anti-PmScl antibodies are characteristic of scleroderma-myositis overlap syndromes. Clinically, patients have features of both systemic sclerosis (sclerodactyly, Raynaud's, skin thickening) and myositis, but ILD with a mechanic's hands is less typical compared to anti-Jo-1.

Anti-collagen (Option D): Anti-collagen antibodies are associated with autoimmune diseases affecting connective tissue structures, such as Goodpasture's syndrome or certain forms of drug-induced autoimmunity. They are not linked with myositis, arthritis, or ILD syndromes like Antisynthetase Syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of necrotizing myopathy?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Steroid-induced myopathy is a toxic (non-inflammatory) myopathy that does not cause necrosis on biopsy; instead, it causes type II muscle fiber atrophy without necrosis or significant inflammation.

Immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy (IMNM) is a distinct type of idiopathic inflammatory myopathy characterized by:

  • Symmetrical, proximal > distal weakness
  • Severe elevation of creatine kinase (CK)
  • Muscle biopsy showing myofiber necrosis with minimal inflammation

The two main autoantibody associations are:

  1. Anti-HMGCR myopathy may be triggered by statins but can also occur without statin exposure.
  2. Anti-SRP myopathy - more aggressive, with a rapid onset and severe weakness.

Explanation of other options:

Anti-SRP myopathy (Option A): Causes a severe form of necrotizing myopathy with profound weakness and markedly high CK. Associated with poor response to standard therapy.

Anti-HMGCR myopathy (Option B): Seen in patients exposed to statins (but can also occur in statin-naïve individuals). Biopsy shows necrosis of muscle fibers with minimal inflammatory infiltrate.

Statin-induced myopathy (Option C): Can lead to toxic myopathy or trigger immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy (anti-HMGCR). The immune-mediated form continues to progress even after statin withdrawal.

questions.text: To which category of vasculitis does Behcet's disease fall?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Behçet disease is classified under variable vessel vasculitis in the 2012 Revised Chapel Hill Consensus Classification.
  • Variable vessel vasculitis is defined as vasculitis that can involve any size of vessel (small, medium, or large), in both arteries and veins.
  • Key features of Behçet disease:
    • Classic triad: Recurrent oral aphthous ulcers, genital ulcers, and ocular lesions (uveitis, retinal vasculitis).
    • It can involve arterial and venous systems, causing DVTs, aneurysms, CNS involvement, and skin manifestations (erythema nodosum, acneiform lesions).

choices.text: The most common and the earliest lesion of Behcet's disease is genital ulcers
The most specific lesion is an oral ulcer
While oral ulcers do scar, genital ulcers usually do not
The pathergy test is a nonspecific hyperreactivity test to trauma

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Behcet's disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Behçet's disease is a variable-vessel vasculitis with multisystem involvement.
  • The earliest and most common lesion:
    • Oral ulcers - seen in almost all patients, usually the first manifestation, recurrent, but rarely leave scars. (Option A ruled out)
  • Most specific lesion:
    • Genital ulcers - these are deeper, larger, heal slowly, and tend to scar, unlike oral ulcers. (Option B & C ruled out)
  • Pathergy test:
    • Represents non-specific hyperreactivity of the skin to trauma.
    • A papule or pustule appears 24-48 hours after a sterile needle prick.
    • Considered unique to Behçet's syndrome and part of the diagnostic criteria.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a history of progressive difficulty in climbing stairs and rising from chairs. She also complains of difficulty swallowing. She complains that her hands discolor and become cold easily. On examination, she has purple discoloration of her eyelids and periorbital oedema. There is a weakness of the muscles of her limb girdles. What is the likely cause of the dysphagia?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

This presentation is most consistent with Dermatomyositis because the patient has:

  • Symmetrical proximal muscle weakness (difficulty climbing stairs, rising from chairs)
  • Heliotrope rash (purple discoloration of eyelids with periorbital edema)
  • Raynaud's phenomenon (hands discolor and become cold)
  • Dysphagia (difficulty swallowing)

Mechanism of dysphagia in DM:

  • In dermatomyositis, dysphagia occurs due to weakness of the striated muscles of the oropharynx and upper esophagus.
  • There may also be inflammation or fibrosis of the cricopharyngeus muscle, which further contributes to difficulty swallowing.

Explanation of other options:

Oesophageal cancer (Option A): Causes progressive dysphagia (solids → liquids), weight loss, and lacks proximal muscle weakness or heliotrope rash.

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) (Option C): May cause arthritis, rashes (malar), and systemic features, but does not typically cause heliotrope rash or muscle weakness with dysphagia.

Retrosternal goitre (Option D): Can cause mechanical compression of the esophagus, but there would be signs of thyroid enlargement and no proximal muscle weakness or skin rash.

questions.text: A 44-year-old patient presents with proximal muscle weakness, particularly in the lower limbs. She has a heliotropic rash around the eyes and also Gottron's papules. Which one of the following antibodies is most strongly associated?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

This is a classic case of Dermatomyositis (DM). The presence of proximal muscle weakness, heliotrope rash, and Gottron's papules makes the diagnosis clear.

Key antibody associations:

  • Anti-MDA5 (Melanoma Differentiation-Associated gene 5): Strongly associated with Dermatomyositis, particularly:
    • Clinically amyopathic DM
    • Severe, rapidly progressive interstitial lung disease (ILD)
    • Cutaneous ulcerations and palmar papules
  • Other DM-specific autoantibodies include Mi-2, TIF-1γ, and NXP2.

Explanation of other options:

La (SS-B) (Option A): Seen in Sjögren's syndrome, not DM.

Ro (SS-A) (Option B): Found in Sjögren's and subacute cutaneous lupus.

SCL-70 (Anti-topoisomerase I) (Option C): Marker of systemic sclerosis (diffuse scleroderma), associated with interstitial lung disease and sclerodactyly.
